So, we all remember the accusations aganist criticizing Bush post 9/11, mainly that anyone who did it was aganist America and a traitor. 
 
 Doesn't that mean that those very people who criticized Clinton are the same? 
 
 I smell hypocrites
A critic isn't necessarily also a hypocrite.

A critic isn't necessarily also a hypocrite.

 
 But the ones who called the critics of Bush unamerican were also the ones criticizng Clinton. Under such logic, they are hypocrites unless they accept they are unamerican as well.

From what I remember, the criticisms leveled against Bush were mainly due to his policies regarding Iraq. Specifically, committing our country to a long expensive war/occupation with very little global support and mixed domestic support. Secondarily, he was/is criticized for uncontrolled spending. He was praised for a tax cut at the Federal level. The rest of our taxes, however, seem to be increasing due to a lack of revenues collected, and decreased funding at the Federal level, as well as uncontrollable spending at all levels of government. I'll be interested to see how he reduces the deficit before he leaves office.

I critiqued Bush for his deceptive rationale regarding Iraq and was labeled unpatriotic. I'm very critical of his fiscal policies and labeled a doomsayer. My criticism of Clinton for his fiscal manipulation of following Bush Sr. in wholesale SS trust looting was rewarded with agreement by fellow conservatives. I stated Clinton degraded his office by sexually consorting with commoners, pointing out that even JFK's prodigious sexual appetites were indulged by ladies shunning public recognition, and was labeled an elitist by party dogs of both primary political persuasions. These judgment threads are confusing.

I stated Clinton degraded his office by sexually consorting with commoners, pointing out that even JFK's prodigious sexual appetites were indulged by ladies shunning public recognition, and was labeled an elitist by party dogs of both primary political persuasions. These judgment threads are confusing
 
 I wasn't aware of JFK's sexual appetites until after his death and there were some stories about he and Marilyn Monroe. I don't think she shunned public recognition, unless you are just talking about blabbing that she and JFK were involved with each other.
 
 If you mean that it was tacky that Clinton had extra marital sex with commoners and that was what degraded his term in office (the fact that the woman was a commoner), I think that is a pompous, arrogant comment and just as hypocritical as any other statement you pointed out. Hypocricy is the false pretense of moral excellence. I don't think anybody's cooter is made of gold.

Commoner? 
 
 This isn't England.

 
 No, but many Americans become extremely upset at being identified by sociodemographic groups (as verified by the prior post) that do in fact exist in spite of their beliefs of equality. My terminology is in direct contrast with the mentality driving the American Dream that historically provided our stable work force; that there's no difference between a President and say a waitress. Bad choice of words on my part, I should have said lower class and really brought out the anger.

But the ones who called the critics of Bush unamerican were also the ones criticizng Clinton. Under such logic, they are hypocrites unless they accept they are unamerican as well.

 
 I think I see your point better now: but perceived hypocrisy is often confused with complexity of attitude.
 
 It's quite possible to separate policies/judgements of which you approve from those you don't, even when they all emanate from the same source.

I think I see your point better now: but perceived hypocrisy is often confused with complexity of attitude.

 
 Perhaps, but as I recall, Clinton was blasted during the 90s on everything by the very same people who now accuse those of criticizing Bush on anything unpatrotic and unamerican. That seems pretty hypocritical to me. 
 
 georged, i'm not (WHOOPS) angry. It's just your indentifying a group that doesn't exist in America.

georged, i'm angry. It's just your indentifying a group that doesn't exist in America.

 Commoners.

We do have economic commoners, but that usually deals with luxury items (have and have nots) and non-celebrity commoners, but that usually deals with how the legal system is applied (Martha Stewart anyone?). But for instances outside of those, commoners don't exist.

 On commoners: There is no place on earth where social differences are more important than in Britain. Even a mere nuance of accent in spoken English can mark you down (or up) the social scale.
 
 I'd like to think this sort of nonsense doesn't exist in the USA; but I expect I'm wrong about this ?

I'd like to think this sort of nonsense doesn't exist in the USA; but I expect I'm wrong about this ?

 
 Yes and no. Economic and non-celeb commoners exist, but those only apply in specific sitautions. I would guess that our system has more to do with perceieved education rather then actual status. Those who speak with a Southern Draw are often charatericzed as less intelligent or less educated. (think about it, do you want your brain surgeon talking in a southern draw? No thanks, I'll just die) However, that doesn't mean they are less educated or intelligent. On the flip side, those who speak as if they are educated and know something are often perceieved as "higher" on the social scale. But once knowledge of bank accounts and net worth is made public, all of that goes out the window. The southern draw alleged "commoner idiot" who has $50 million in land is no longer a "commoner idiot."

 Just to focus on accent for a minute:
 I guessed that the Southern Draw (we call it "drawl") might be one of the factors in "placing" someone in the social scale. Can you tell (or do you think you can tell) as soon as someone opens his mouth, what part of the US he hails from ? Is there a hierarchy of accents - say the "Kennedy tone" from Boston at the top of the register and the Alabama backwoods voice somehow near the bottom ? 
 I'm not sure about this sort of thing in America, but here I can "place" anyone within seconds if they have a regional accent. British people make a judgment about you based on the sound of your vowels - crazy isn't it ?

 I have strong West of Scotland(Glaswegian) accent and I have experienced the very same thing in England. I went to a very posh Restaurant in Brighton and as soon as the Waiter heard my accent I was treated very shabbily indeed. I am actually worried about my chances of getting a job down in England because people might unfairly judge me because of my accent. It's less of a problem in Scotland I believe, but you still get some people judging you on your accent.
 
 But at least in America a 'Commoner' and can have sexual relations :) with the Head of State, I couldn't imagine a commoner doing the same with the Queen. At least America has eliminated that sort of class barrier.

On commoners: There is no place on earth where social differences are more important than in Britain. Even a mere nuance of accent in spoken English can mark you down (or up) the social scale.
 
 I'd like to think this sort of nonsense doesn't exist in the USA; but I expect I'm wrong about this ?

 
 I stood corrected, 'commoner' is not a term normally used in the US when referring to class distinctions. Class distinctions do exist in the US in a variety of definitions, as they do in every country I've visited, primarily on an economic basis. Most Americans have swallowed the equality belief used to motivate them to a point where lower and middle classes function well within that strata without recognition of inferior legal services (Martha Stewart excepted, that went a long ways in making people feel equal), college acceptance, many medical services, place of residence and on and on and on. I guess someone could drag out the old argument of discrimination by socioeconomic status, but I haven't heard that one since school years.

But at least in America a 'Commoner' and can have sexual relations :) with the Head of State, I couldn't imagine a commoner doing the same with the Queen. At least America has eliminated that sort of class barrier.

 
 One head of state did just that, most who pursued sexual affairs were far more discrete.

Yes and no. Economic and non-celeb commoners exist, but those only apply in specific sitautions. I would guess that our system has more to do with perceieved education rather then actual status. Those who speak with a Southern Draw are often charatericzed as less intelligent or less educated. (think about it, do you want your brain surgeon talking in a southern draw? No thanks, I'll just die) However, that doesn't mean they are less educated or intelligent. On the flip side, those who speak as if they are educated and know something are often perceieved as "higher" on the social scale. But once knowledge of bank accounts and net worth is made public, all of that goes out the window. The southern draw alleged "commoner idiot" who has $50 million in land is no longer a "commoner idiot."

 
 Believe me when I say balance sheet alone is not a true equalizer when it comes to social status. There are golf clubs, private clubs, schools, civic organizations, co-opted apartment buildings, residential developments and many, many other associations where bankroll is a primary requirement but doesn't qualify an individual for admission. The blackball is still alive and well in America.

I stood corrected, 'commoner' is not a term normally used in the US when referring to class distinctions. Class distinctions do exist in the US in a variety of definitions, as they do in every country I've visited, primarily on an economic basis. Most Americans have swallowed the equality belief used to motivate them to a point where lower and middle classes function well within that strata without recognition of inferior legal services (Martha Stewart excepted, that went a long ways in making people feel equal), college acceptance, many medical services, place of residence and on and on and on. I guess someone could drag out the old argument of discrimination by socioeconomic status, but I haven't heard that one since school years.

 
 I also believe that class distinctions exist in every modern society. But some distinctions are more subtle and some more fatuous than others.
 
 On the feeble basis of my infrequent visits to relatives in Chicago, who to my ear speak "regular American" (perhaps it's a mid-Western accent, for all I know), I've concluded that the mere sound of your vowels, let alone what is said, doesn't signify a social level in the US in quite the same way that I'm accustomed to here. 
 
 I guess, like everywhere else, there is an "educated voice" in America - but it doesn't command deferential obedience by the listeners.

 I asserted no such thing: I asked a question about the "hierarchy" of accents in America - if there is such a phenomenon.
 
 Why don't you read the post properly (if you can be bothered) before jumping in with your charges of "absurdity" ?

Believe me when I say balance sheet alone is not a true equalizer when it comes to social status. There are golf clubs, private clubs, schools, civic organizations, co-opted apartment buildings, residential developments and many, many other associations where bankroll is a primary requirement but doesn't qualify an individual for admission. The blackball is still alive and well in America.

 
 Certainly, though I don't think people realize it. There are plenty of clubs out there that require sponsorship for membership as well as a general vote of members. These are the places that things get done, elbows get rubbed, and all the behind the scenes deal making goes on.
 
 Around here (Kansas and Missouri), it would be the Kansas city club. Membership guarantees access to all those juicy government contracts that nobody seems to be able to get, insider information regarding corporate happenings, and preferential treatment should you ever find yourself in hot water from a legal standpoint, since almost all prominent attorneys in Ks and Missouri are members, not to mention the attorney generals of both states (not in the old days when the AG of Kansas was a woman. The Kansas City Club is men only). 
 
 A couple hours in the smoking room on any given Friday night will net you stock tips worth thousands, insider tracks on a couple of major contracts, and solve any compliance issues you might have at the city or state level. 
 
 Membership, far from being decided based on wealth, which comes and goes, is decided on prominence and the ability to get things done, namely your value to the other members. It is one of the few places on the planet you are likely to see local organized crime figures enjoying a drink with the state attorney general. 
 
 It is old boy deal making at its finest, and with an excellent cigar bar to boot. No commoners allowed, of course.

It is old boy deal making at its finest, and with an excellent cigar bar to boot. No commoners allowed, of course.

 I'd say that's pretty close to the accent heirarchy here.
